messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] okay, this is a stupid question - kodachi
messages.msgSnippet: Okay, I was just wondering, this is really interiging. Richardson Paul  wrote:HI I guess like any weapon it would be used for either attack
messages.messageBody:
Okay, I was just wondering, this is really interiging.

Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:HI

I guess like any weapon it would be used for either
attack or defense.

as the kata I do start with you both facing each othe
rwirth baldes drawn I would say it could that either
one is on the offensive.

with the kukishinden ryu kodachi kata moving in such a
way to make an opening then I would say it could be
either

Paul

--- andrea Smith <andjoysmith@...> wrote:


---------------------------------
This is so cool. I have a question...is the kodachi
basicly used for defense?

Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:
Hi

the kodachi I have (Iaito) is the same length as any
long wakizashi. The wood one i have is also the same
length, I was pleased to find one form Japan that was
the same.

I can measure the blade length if needed.

The trsuka is a standard wakizashi length handle

paul


--- Dean Wayland
wrote:


---------------------------------
Hi Paul,

Any idea of this kodachi's actual dimensions, blade
and grip length
etc.?

Yours

Dean


In message
<20041003193628.84747.qmail@...>,
Richardson Paul writes
> HI
>
> I just recieved a pick of a kodachi that once
belonged
> to a very famoius member of the Yagyu family
dated
> about 1600. it has just been repolished and is
about
> to be submitted for new papers elevating it to a
> national treasure I will ask if I can post the
pic I
> was sent
>
> paul
>
>
> --- andrea Smith wrote:
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> Ah, i'm not a member, I'm just very interested.
This
> very interesting.
>
> Thanks, it helps a lot!
>
> Richardson Paul wrote:
> HI
>
> here is a brief description. I wont go into
details to
> much as I assume you are not a member of either
ryu.
>
> kukishinden Ryu (KSDR) Kodachi has only 3 kata
for the
> use of the kodachi. Once source I know may try to
say
> there are a further 7 ura gata for these 3 omote
gata,
> but i have seen a Kukishin ryu densho and no ura
gata
> were listed in it.
>
> In each one the attacker will come at you with a
> katana and he is trying to cut across at your
torso.
> The reason for this is you are moving around him
and
> you decide when to expose a weak point therefore
> making him attack the area you choose. Once he
does in
> all three you rush in fast and thrust the kodachi
into
> him.
>
> In Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu (HYR), I have not studied.
I
> have been shown the kata once and I have them on
> video. therefore cant describe them properly.
>
> There are five omote kata and I am told maybe
some ura
> gata (which I have not seen or know of). They
like the
> Kuki kodachi involve thrusting and a few slashing
such
> as to the neck or torso.
>
> The HYR tend to sink lower in kamae than the
KSDR.
>
> However there is a historical link between the
two
> ryu.
>
> Kukishinden Ryu is really called Kukishinden
Happo
> Biken, and originates from Kukishin ryu (main
branch
> of that is now Kukishinden Tenshin Hyoho) This
all
> originates from the Kuki family who are today
still
> soke of the tenshin hyoho branch, and also head
> priests of the Kuki shrine. IN the 1600s Ohkuni
Onihei
> was a shihan in the Kukishin ryu and met with
Takagi
> Gennoshin from Takagi Yoshin ryu. together they
> exchanged ideas etc and Takagi Yoshin ryu was
changed.
> Kukishin ryu Bojutsu was added to Takagi. In the
early
> 1900's Ishitani (Ishiya) sensei on his death bed
> handed menkyo kaiden makimono for the Takagi
Yoshin
> ryu to Takamatsu Toshitsugu, they were to be
passed to
> Kakuno one of his students. Both Kakuno and
Takamatsu
> held menkyo Kaiden in Takagi Yoshin Ryu and
kukishin
> Ryu. sort time later Minaki sensei is handed
menkyo
> kaiden in the kakuno takagi ryu and from him him
the
> HYR is developed.
>
> for more indepth info and lines history check out
> these sites.
>
> http://www.hontaiyoshinryu.com/
> http://www.hyrusa.com/index2.html
> http://www.shinjin.co.jp/kuki/hyoho/index_e.html
> http://kobe.cool.ne.jp/ikkansai/takagiryu.htm
> http://www.hanako.co.uk/History.htm (my web
site)
>
> paul
>
>
>
> --- andrea Smith wrote:
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> what's the difference between the Kukishinden Ryu
> Kodachi and the Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu Kodachi? This
is
> pretty interesting!
>
> Richardson Paul wrote:Hi
>
> what explaination would you like. I have studied
> Kukishinden Ryu Kodachi and been shown Hon Tai
Yoshin
> Ryu Kodachi.
>
>
> Paul
>
>
> --- andrea Smith wrote:
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> Ah, thank you. I'd like to get the explantion of
the
> Ryu of the kodachi. *slaps self*
>
> Richardson Paul wrote:Hi
>
> in some cases the kodachi is also regarded as a
> wakizashi.
>
> Several Ryu still teach the use of the kodachi,
two I
> can name are Kukishinden Ryu (3 kata) and HonTai
> Yoshin Ryu (5 kata and I think some ura gata).
>
> paul
>
>
> --- andjoysmith wrote:
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> Okay, I know this is a very studid, but I was
> wondering about the
> kodachi and what it was used for. Really help me
out.
> What is the
> kodachi used for? Slap me if you like, please!
>
>
>

I guess like any weapon it would be used for either

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] okay, this is a stupid question - kodachi
messages.msgSnippet: This is so cool. I have a question...is the kodachi basicly used for defense? Richardson Paul  wrote: Hi the kodachi I have (Iaito) is the
messages.messageBody:
This is so cool. I have a question...is the kodachi basicly used for defense?

Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:
Hi

the kodachi I have (Iaito) is the same length as any
long wakizashi. The wood one i have is also the same
length, I was pleased to find one form Japan that was
the same.

I can measure the blade length if needed.

The trsuka is a standard wakizashi length handle

paul


--- Dean Wayland
wrote:


---------------------------------
Hi Paul,

Any idea of this kodachi's actual dimensions, blade
and grip length
etc.?

Yours

Dean


In message
<20041003193628.84747.qmail@...>,
Richardson Paul writes
> HI
>
> I just recieved a pick of a kodachi that once
belonged
> to a very famoius member of the Yagyu family
dated
> about 1600. it has just been repolished and is
about
> to be submitted for new papers elevating it to a
> national treasure I will ask if I can post the
pic I
> was sent
>
> paul
>
>
> --- andrea Smith wrote:
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> Ah, i'm not a member, I'm just very interested.
This
> very interesting.
>
> Thanks, it helps a lot!
>
> Richardson Paul wrote:
> HI
>
> here is a brief description. I wont go into
details to
> much as I assume you are not a member of either
ryu.
>
> kukishinden Ryu (KSDR) Kodachi has only 3 kata
for the
> use of the kodachi. Once source I know may try to
say
> there are a further 7 ura gata for these 3 omote
gata,
> but i have seen a Kukishin ryu densho and no ura
gata
> were listed in it.
>
> In each one the attacker will come at you with a
> katana and he is trying to cut across at your
torso.
> The reason for this is you are moving around him
and
> you decide when to expose a weak point therefore
> making him attack the area you choose. Once he
does in
> all three you rush in fast and thrust the kodachi
into
> him.
>
> In Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu (HYR), I have not studied.
I
> have been shown the kata once and I have them on
> video. therefore cant describe them properly.
>
> There are five omote kata and I am told maybe
some ura
> gata (which I have not seen or know of). They
like the
> Kuki kodachi involve thrusting and a few slashing
such
> as to the neck or torso.
>
> The HYR tend to sink lower in kamae than the
KSDR.
>
> However there is a historical link between the
two
> ryu.
>
> Kukishinden Ryu is really called Kukishinden
Happo
> Biken, and originates from Kukishin ryu (main
branch
> of that is now Kukishinden Tenshin Hyoho) This
all
> originates from the Kuki family who are today
still
> soke of the tenshin hyoho branch, and also head
> priests of the Kuki shrine. IN the 1600s Ohkuni
Onihei
> was a shihan in the Kukishin ryu and met with
Takagi
> Gennoshin from Takagi Yoshin ryu. together they
> exchanged ideas etc and Takagi Yoshin ryu was
changed.
> Kukishin ryu Bojutsu was added to Takagi. In the
early
> 1900's Ishitani (Ishiya) sensei on his death bed
> handed menkyo kaiden makimono for the Takagi
Yoshin
> ryu to Takamatsu Toshitsugu, they were to be
passed to
> Kakuno one of his students. Both Kakuno and
Takamatsu
> held menkyo Kaiden in Takagi Yoshin Ryu and
kukishin
> Ryu. sort time later Minaki sensei is handed
menkyo
> kaiden in the kakuno takagi ryu and from him him
the
> HYR is developed.
>
> for more indepth info and lines history check out
> these sites.
>
> http://www.hontaiyoshinryu.com/
> http://www.hyrusa.com/index2.html
> http://www.shinjin.co.jp/kuki/hyoho/index_e.html
> http://kobe.cool.ne.jp/ikkansai/takagiryu.htm
> http://www.hanako.co.uk/History.htm (my web
site)
>
> paul
>
>
>
> --- andrea Smith wrote:
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> what's the difference between the Kukishinden Ryu
> Kodachi and the Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu Kodachi? This
is
> pretty interesting!
>
> Richardson Paul wrote:Hi
>
> what explaination would you like. I have studied
> Kukishinden Ryu Kodachi and been shown Hon Tai
Yoshin
> Ryu Kodachi.
>
>
> Paul
>
>
> --- andrea Smith wrote:
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> Ah, thank you. I'd like to get the explantion of
the
> Ryu of the kodachi. *slaps self*
>
> Richardson Paul wrote:Hi
>
> in some cases the kodachi is also regarded as a
> wakizashi.
>
> Several Ryu still teach the use of the kodachi,
two I
> can name are Kukishinden Ryu (3 kata) and HonTai
> Yoshin Ryu (5 kata and I think some ura gata).
>
> paul
>
>
> --- andjoysmith wrote:
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> Okay, I know this is a very studid, but I was
> wondering about the
> kodachi and what it was used for. Really help me
out.
> What is the
> kodachi used for? Slap me if you like, please!
>
>

paul

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: okay, this is a stupid question
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, it sure does, I have never been more interested in a sword as I am right now. Tom Helm  wrote:All- Remember that we are talking
messages.messageBody:
Yes, it sure does, I have never been more interested in a sword as I am right now.

Tom Helm <junkmail@...> wrote:All-
Remember that we are talking about 1000 years of history here. A
kodachi is many things sometimes difficult to distinguish.In
archaeology, its earliest incarnation was a dagger and several
different forms of knife were called kodachi. Several different
combinations of kanji were used as well. Later kodachi was used to
describe a short katana and then wakizashi as in the usage common in
Koryu Kenjutsu schools.
In the world of ART SWORDS, a kodachi is a very specific thing or
things; for students of nihonto a kodachi is an early blade in classic
tachi shape signed in tachi style on the haki-omote but half again (or
less) smaller in overall proportions. Lacking the tachi signature a
blade might be called kodachi if mounted in tachi koshirae. However
small blades in elaborate tachi koshirae were made for and used by the
members of the Emperors court, these bejewelled "Kazari"tachi were
small but not meant for real use so there is a distinction drawn.
So if you are talking kodachi, it helps to keep your audience in mind,
are we talkin Kofun, kantei, Koryu or Kozure Okami?
-t

In message <20041003193628.84747.qmail@...>,
Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> writes
> HI
>
> I just recieved a pick of a kodachi that once belonged
> to a very famoius member of the Yagyu family dated
> about 1600. it has just been repolished and is about
> to be submitted for new papers elevating it to a
> national treasure I will ask if I can post the pic I
> was sent
>
> paul
>
>
> --- andrea Smith <andjoysmith@...> wrote:
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> Ah, i'm not a member, I'm just very interested. This
> very interesting.
>
> Thanks, it helps a lot!
>
> Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:
> HI
>
> here is a brief description. I wont go into details to
> much as I assume you are not a member of either ryu.
>
> kukishinden Ryu (KSDR) Kodachi has only 3 kata for the
> use of the kodachi. Once source I know may try to say
> there are a further 7 ura gata for these 3 omote gata,
> but i have seen a Kukishin ryu densho and no ura gata
> were listed in it.
>
> In each one the attacker will come at you with a
> katana and he is trying to cut across at your torso.
> The reason for this is you are moving around him and
> you decide when to expose a weak point therefore
> making him attack the area you choose. Once he does in
> all three you rush in fast and thrust the kodachi into
> him.
>
> In Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu (HYR), I have not studied. I
> have been shown the kata once and I have them on
> video. therefore cant describe them properly.
>
> There are five omote kata and I am told maybe some ura
> gata (which I have not seen or know of). They like the
> Kuki kodachi involve thrusting and a few slashing such
> as to the neck or torso.
>
> The HYR tend to sink lower in kamae than the KSDR.
>
> However there is a historical link between the two
> ryu.
>
> Kukishinden Ryu is really called Kukishinden Happo
> Biken, and originates from Kukishin ryu (main branch
> of that is now Kukishinden Tenshin Hyoho) This all
> originates from the Kuki family who are today still
> soke of the tenshin hyoho branch, and also head
> priests of the Kuki shrine. IN the 1600s Ohkuni Onihei
> was a shihan in the Kukishin ryu and met with Takagi
> Gennoshin from Takagi Yoshin ryu. together they
> exchanged ideas etc and Takagi Yoshin ryu was changed.
> Kukishin ryu Bojutsu was added to Takagi. In the early
> 1900's Ishitani (Ishiya) sensei on his death bed
> handed menkyo kaiden makimono for the Takagi Yoshin
> ryu to Takamatsu Toshitsugu, they were to be passed to
> Kakuno one of his students. Both Kakuno and Takamatsu
> held menkyo Kaiden in Takagi Yoshin Ryu and kukishin
> Ryu. sort time later Minaki sensei is handed menkyo
> kaiden in the kakuno takagi ryu and from him him the
> HYR is developed.
>
> for more indepth info and lines history check out
> these sites.
>
> http://www.hontaiyoshinryu.com/
> http://www.hyrusa.com/index2.html
> http://www.shinjin.co.jp/kuki/hyoho/index_e.html
> http://kobe.cool.ne.jp/ikkansai/takagiryu.htm
> http://www.hanako.co.uk/History.htm (my web site)
>
> paul
>
>
>
> --- andrea Smith <andjoysmith@...> wrote:
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> what's the difference between the Kukishinden Ryu
> Kodachi and the Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu Kodachi? This is
> pretty interesting!
>
> Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:Hi
>
> what explaination would you like. I have studied
> Kukishinden Ryu Kodachi and been shown Hon Tai Yoshin
> Ryu Kodachi.
>
>
> Paul
>

> paul

messages.msgSnippet: All- Remember that we are talking about 1000 years of history here. A kodachi is many things sometimes difficult to distinguish.In archaeology, its earliest
messages.messageBody:
All-
Remember that we are talking about 1000 years of history here. A
kodachi is many things sometimes difficult to distinguish.In
archaeology, its earliest incarnation was a dagger and several
different forms of knife were called kodachi. Several different
combinations of kanji were used as well. Later kodachi was used to
describe a short katana and then wakizashi as in the usage common in
Koryu Kenjutsu schools.
In the world of ART SWORDS, a kodachi is a very specific thing or
things; for students of nihonto a kodachi is an early blade in classic
tachi shape signed in tachi style on the haki-omote but half again (or
less) smaller in overall proportions. Lacking the tachi signature a
blade might be called kodachi if mounted in tachi koshirae. However
small blades in elaborate tachi koshirae were made for and used by the
members of the Emperors court, these bejewelled "Kazari"tachi were
small but not meant for real use so there is a distinction drawn.
So if you are talking kodachi, it helps to keep your audience in mind,
are we talkin Kofun, kantei, Koryu or Kozure Okami?
-t

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: okay, this is a stupid question
messages.msgSnippet: Yeah, I kind of knew that, I have watched the anime before. Of course, I do agree. Saitoh Hajime  wrote: The Kodachi is a sword, ranged
messages.messageBody:
Yeah, I kind of knew that, I have watched the anime before. Of course, I do agree.

Saitoh Hajime <the_sam_99@...> wrote:
The Kodachi is a sword, ranged between the wakizashi and the katana.

Then again, I'm only speaking from what I know of the kodachi thanks
to Rurouni Kenshin, not a bad source but not the highest reputed either.

Miburo

messages.msgSnippet: I d like to see the picture, I never seen a picture of a kodachi. Richardson Paul  wrote:HI I just recieved a pick of a kodachi that once
messages.messageBody:
I'd like to see the picture, I never seen a picture of a kodachi.

Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:HI

I just recieved a pick of a kodachi that once belonged
to a very famoius member of the Yagyu family dated
about 1600. it has just been repolished and is about
to be submitted for new papers elevating it to a
national treasure I will ask if I can post the pic I
was sent

paul


--- andrea Smith <andjoysmith@...> wrote:


---------------------------------
Ah, i'm not a member, I'm just very interested. This
very interesting.

Thanks, it helps a lot!

Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:
HI

here is a brief description. I wont go into details to
much as I assume you are not a member of either ryu.

kukishinden Ryu (KSDR) Kodachi has only 3 kata for the
use of the kodachi. Once source I know may try to say
there are a further 7 ura gata for these 3 omote gata,
but i have seen a Kukishin ryu densho and no ura gata
were listed in it.

In each one the attacker will come at you with a
katana and he is trying to cut across at your torso.
The reason for this is you are moving around him and
you decide when to expose a weak point therefore
making him attack the area you choose. Once he does in
all three you rush in fast and thrust the kodachi into
him.

In Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu (HYR), I have not studied. I
have been shown the kata once and I have them on
video. therefore cant describe them properly.

There are five omote kata and I am told maybe some ura
gata (which I have not seen or know of). They like the
Kuki kodachi involve thrusting and a few slashing such
as to the neck or torso.

The HYR tend to sink lower in kamae than the KSDR.

However there is a historical link between the two
ryu.

Kukishinden Ryu is really called Kukishinden Happo
Biken, and originates from Kukishin ryu (main branch
of that is now Kukishinden Tenshin Hyoho) This all
originates from the Kuki family who are today still
soke of the tenshin hyoho branch, and also head
priests of the Kuki shrine. IN the 1600s Ohkuni Onihei
was a shihan in the Kukishin ryu and met with Takagi
Gennoshin from Takagi Yoshin ryu. together they
exchanged ideas etc and Takagi Yoshin ryu was changed.
Kukishin ryu Bojutsu was added to Takagi. In the early
1900's Ishitani (Ishiya) sensei on his death bed
handed menkyo kaiden makimono for the Takagi Yoshin
ryu to Takamatsu Toshitsugu, they were to be passed to
Kakuno one of his students. Both Kakuno and Takamatsu
held menkyo Kaiden in Takagi Yoshin Ryu and kukishin
Ryu. sort time later Minaki sensei is handed menkyo
kaiden in the kakuno takagi ryu and from him him the
HYR is developed.

for more indepth info and lines history check out
these sites.

http://www.hontaiyoshinryu.com/
http://www.hyrusa.com/index2.html
http://www.shinjin.co.jp/kuki/hyoho/index_e.html
http://kobe.cool.ne.jp/ikkansai/takagiryu.htm
http://www.hanako.co.uk/History.htm (my web site)

paul



--- andrea Smith <andjoysmith@...> wrote:


---------------------------------
what's the difference between the Kukishinden Ryu
Kodachi and the Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu Kodachi? This is
pretty interesting!

Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:Hi

what explaination would you like. I have studied
Kukishinden Ryu Kodachi and been shown Hon Tai Yoshin
Ryu Kodachi.


Paul

Several Ryu still teach the use of the kodachi, two I

Yoshin Ryu (5 kata and I think some ura gata).

paul

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] okay, this is a stupid question - kodachi
messages.msgSnippet: Ah, i m not a member, I m just very interested. This very interesting. Thanks, it helps a lot! Richardson Paul  wrote: HI here is a brief
messages.messageBody:
Ah, i'm not a member, I'm just very interested. This very interesting.

Thanks, it helps a lot!

Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:
HI

here is a brief description. I wont go into details to
much as I assume you are not a member of either ryu.

kukishinden Ryu (KSDR) Kodachi has only 3 kata for the
use of the kodachi. Once source I know may try to say
there are a further 7 ura gata for these 3 omote gata,
but i have seen a Kukishin ryu densho and no ura gata
were listed in it.

In each one the attacker will come at you with a
katana and he is trying to cut across at your torso.
The reason for this is you are moving around him and
you decide when to expose a weak point therefore
making him attack the area you choose. Once he does in
all three you rush in fast and thrust the kodachi into
him.

In Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu (HYR), I have not studied. I
have been shown the kata once and I have them on
video. therefore cant describe them properly.

There are five omote kata and I am told maybe some ura
gata (which I have not seen or know of). They like the
Kuki kodachi involve thrusting and a few slashing such
as to the neck or torso.

The HYR tend to sink lower in kamae than the KSDR.

However there is a historical link between the two
ryu.

Kukishinden Ryu is really called Kukishinden Happo
Biken, and originates from Kukishin ryu (main branch
of that is now Kukishinden Tenshin Hyoho) This all
originates from the Kuki family who are today still
soke of the tenshin hyoho branch, and also head
priests of the Kuki shrine. IN the 1600s Ohkuni Onihei
was a shihan in the Kukishin ryu and met with Takagi
Gennoshin from Takagi Yoshin ryu. together they
exchanged ideas etc and Takagi Yoshin ryu was changed.
Kukishin ryu Bojutsu was added to Takagi. In the early
1900's Ishitani (Ishiya) sensei on his death bed
handed menkyo kaiden makimono for the Takagi Yoshin
ryu to Takamatsu Toshitsugu, they were to be passed to
Kakuno one of his students. Both Kakuno and Takamatsu
held menkyo Kaiden in Takagi Yoshin Ryu and kukishin
Ryu. sort time later Minaki sensei is handed menkyo
kaiden in the kakuno takagi ryu and from him him the
HYR is developed.

for more indepth info and lines history check out
these sites.

http://www.hontaiyoshinryu.com/
http://www.hyrusa.com/index2.html
http://www.shinjin.co.jp/kuki/hyoho/index_e.html
http://kobe.cool.ne.jp/ikkansai/takagiryu.htm
http://www.hanako.co.uk/History.htm (my web site)

paul

Paul

in some cases the kodachi is also regarded as a

Several Ryu still teach the use of the kodachi, two I

It's regarded as a wakizashi????That means the kodachi is a sword.

Edy

Yoshin Ryu (5 kata and I think some ura gata).

paul
